## Article: The Moon

## Passage:
The Moon
    
    
        Look up in the sky at night. What do you see? If it is not cloudy, you may be able to see the moon. When you see the moon at night, it might look white. It might look gray or silver. Sometimes, it seems to shine and glow. But the moon does not give off light the way the sun does. The moon is a ball of rock that gives off no light of its own. It simply reflects light from the sun. That means light from the sun hits the moon and bounces off.
You already know that Earth goes around the sun. But did you know that the moon goes around Earth? It takes about one month for the moon to completely circle Earth. If you look up at the night sky each night of the month, you may think that the size and shape of the moon is changing. However, the size and shape are not really changing. The moon is still a round ball. It looks different at different times of the month because of the way the light from the sun bounces off it and how much of the moon we can see from Earth.

---

The moon has different phases during the month. If you looked at the moon each night for a month, you would see it change from a thin slice to a full circle and back again. You can see how the moon seems to change during the month. The moon goes through the same pattern every month. First it looks like a thin slice. Then it gets bigger and bigger until it looks like a full circle. After that, it gets smaller and smaller until you can barely see it at all.
The way that Earth, the moon, and the sun move can also make other interesting things to look at in the sky. When Earth, the moon, and the sun all move together in a straight line, something special called an eclipse can take place. We can see two kinds of eclipses from Earth.

---

One kind of eclipse happens when the moon gets in between the sun and Earth. When that happens, we can't see the sun for a while. At least, we can't see part of it. We call this a solar eclipse or an eclipse of the sun. During this kind of eclipse, the moon moves between Earth and the sun and blocks out the sun's light.
The other kind of eclipse is called a lunar eclipse. This also involves the sun, the moon, and Earth. It takes place when the moon passes behind Earth and into its shadow. During a lunar eclipse, Earth's shadow covers part of the moon. Earth has blocked out the sun and left part of the moon in darkness.

---

Eclipses do not happen often because the sun, Earth, and the moon all have to line up just right. Solar eclipses can only be seen from a small strip of Earth at a time. While they happen once or twice a year, it is very rare to see one. Lunar eclipses happen more often, several times each year. They can be seen from half of Earth at a time, so more people can see them.
Whether or not you can see an eclipse depends on where you are on Earth. You must never look directly at a solar eclipse. The sun is very bright and could hurt your eyes badly. But it is safe to look at a lunar eclipse. If an eclipse is going to happen, it is usually big news. You will likely hear about it on TV or read about it online.

The Planets Closest to the Sun: Mercury, Venus, Earth, and Mars
    
    
        Our planet Earth is one of eight planets in our solar system. All of these planets move around the sun in a path called an orbit. The other planets are Mercury, Venus, Mars, Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, and Neptune. People have been looking at the planets for thousands of years. Long ago, people from places like Mesopotamia, Greece, and ancient civilizations like the Mayans, Incas, and Aztecs were all interested in the planets. They used just their naked eye to study the planets in the night sky. This means they looked at the planets without any special tools to help them see better. Now, we have telescopes and other amazing tools that help us get a much better look at the planets.

---

The four planets closest to the sun are Mercury, Venus, Earth, and Mars. These are small planets with rocky, solid surfaces that you could walk on if you had the right equipment. Mercury and Venus are closer to the sun than Earth, while Mars is farther away. Earth needs 365 days to make one complete orbit around the sun. That is exactly the length of one year on Earth. The closer a planet is to the sun, the less time it needs to make one orbit. Mercury is the closest planet to the sun, so it moves the fastest. It needs just 88 days to make one orbit around the sun. Venus is the next closest to the sun and needs 225 days to make its orbit. The planets that are farther away take much longer to complete their journey. It takes Neptune an amazing 165 years to orbit the sun just one time!

---

Mercury is not only the closest planet to the sun, but it is also the smallest of all the planets in our solar system. The English name for this planet comes from the Romans, who named it after their god Mercury. The Greeks called this same god Hermes. Venus is the second planet from the sun and is the planet closest to Earth. This bright planet was named after the Roman goddess of love. For a long time, scientists thought that Venus might be very similar to Earth. After all, it is close to Earth in space, it is about the same size as Earth, and it is covered with thick clouds, just like Earth.

---

But scientists discovered that their idea about Venus was completely wrong. We know now that Venus and Earth are different in many important ways. Scientists had to change their ideas when they learned new facts about Venus. They have now concluded that Venus is much hotter than Earth and would not be a good place for us to live or even visit. Mars is the fourth planet from the sun and is named after the Roman god of war. When you look at Mars in the night sky, it appears quite red. This red color comes from rocks on Mars that contain rust. Many space probes and robots have landed on Mars to explore this interesting planet. They have taken thousands of photographs and dug up rocks to study. One probe found some ice on Mars, which was very exciting news. Ice is frozen water, and if there is water on Mars, there might be life there too.

## Passage:
The Outer Planets: Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, and Neptune
    
    
        Do you remember the names of the four planets closest to the sun? If you said, "Mercury, Venus, Earth, and Mars," you are right! There are four more planets called the outer planets. So there are eight planets in all. Jupiter is the very next planet after Mars. After Jupiter come Saturn, Uranus, and Neptune in that order. Neptune is the planet that is farthest from the sun.
Uranus is hard to see with just your eyes. Neptune is impossible to see without help. You need a telescope to see Neptune. A telescope is a special tool that makes faraway things look bigger and closer.

---

The outer planets are very different from Earth. They are much bigger than the inner planets. They are also made mostly of gas instead of rock. Scientists call these planets gas giants because they are so huge and made of gas. Of all the planets, Jupiter is the largest. It is so big that 1,300 Earths could fit inside it! Jupiter is made mostly of hydrogen gas. This is the most common gas in the whole universe.
The gases on Jupiter are always moving around. When you look at pictures of Jupiter, you can see a giant red spot. It looks like a big eye! Scientists think this red spot is actually a huge storm. It is like a hurricane, but much bigger than any storm on Earth. This storm has been going on for hundreds of years. Jupiter also has 63 moons that go around it. Some of these moons are very large. They are even bigger than Earth's moon!

---

Saturn is famous for something very special. It has many large rings that go around the planet. These rings are made of ice and dust. The ice reflects light from the sun. This makes the rings shine and glow. Saturn looks beautiful because of its bright rings. Saturn also has many moons that orbit around it, just like Jupiter does.
The last two planets are Uranus and Neptune. These planets are the farthest from the sun. Because they are so far away, they are very cold places. Uranus and Neptune also have rings around them. But their rings are much harder to see than Saturn's rings. Both planets also have moons that orbit around them.

---

Now you know the names of all eight planets in our solar system! Try asking the adults in your family how many planets there are. They may tell you that there are nine planets. When the adults in your family were in school, people said there was a ninth planet called Pluto. But in 2006, scientists looked at Pluto more carefully. They decided that Pluto did not have all the right characteristics to be called a planet. Scientists removed Pluto's name from the list of planets. So now there are only eight planets in our solar system.

Asteroids, Comets, and Meteors
    
    
        Our solar system has many amazing objects that travel around the sun. You already know about the eight planets, but there are millions of other space rocks too! These rocks come in different sizes and are made of different things.
Asteroids are some of the most common space rocks in our solar system. They are made of rock, metal, and sometimes ice. Most asteroids live in a special place between Mars and Jupiter. They group together like a giant ring around the sun. Scientists call this the asteroid belt because it looks like a belt wrapped around our solar system.

---

Another type of space object is called a comet. Comets are very different from asteroids. They are made mostly of ice and dust, like giant dirty snowballs flying through space! When a comet gets close to the sun, something amazing happens. The sun's heat makes some of the ice turn into gas. This gas streams behind the comet and looks like a long, bright tail.
The most famous comet is called Halley's Comet. It got its name from Edmund Halley, a British scientist who first studied it. This special comet can be seen from Earth without a telescope every 76 years. People last saw it in 1986. Can you figure out when it will come back again?

---

There are also smaller space rocks called meteoroids floating throughout our solar system. These rocks are much smaller than asteroids. When a meteoroid flies into Earth's atmosphere, we call it a meteor. The atmosphere is the layer of air that surrounds our planet like a protective blanket.
As the meteor rushes through the atmosphere, it burns up and creates a bright white trail across the sky. People sometimes call this a "shooting star," even though it's not really a star at all! Have you ever seen one streak across the night sky?

---

Sometimes many meteors can be seen falling on the same night. This is called a meteor shower, and it creates an amazing space show that can last for several nights. Most meteors burn up completely in the atmosphere.
However, if a meteor doesn't burn up all the way, it can crash into Earth's surface. When this happens, it can make a large hole called a crater. The pieces of the meteor that are found on the ground are called meteorites. Our planet Earth is shaped like a sphere, which means it's round like a ball, so meteorites can land anywhere on its surface.

## Article: Galaxies and Stars

## Passage:
Galaxies and Stars
    
    
        Look up in the sky at night. What do you see besides the moon? If it is not cloudy, you can see lots of stars shining in the sky. Remember that the sun is also a star. The stars in the night sky do not look like the sun. They do not look as big or as bright. But they are really very much alike. The stars in the night sky are big balls of hot gas, just like the sun.
So why don't they look the same? The night stars are much, much farther away from Earth than the sun. That is why they look like tiny dots of light. If we could get close to the stars, they would look bigger, brighter, and more like the sun. But the stars we see at night are so far away that no one from Earth has ever been able to get close to them.

---

Scientists who study the stars and outer space are called astronomers. The Greek root word astron means star. The prefix astro is used in many other English words. All stars are big balls of hot gas, but astronomers have found that stars are different in many ways. Stars can be different sizes and colors. Some stars are closer to Earth than others and some stars are hotter than others. Stars that are the hottest and closest to Earth appear brighter than other stars.

---

Astronomers also found that stars group together in large clusters. A large group of stars that cluster together in one area is called a galaxy. There are billions and billions of stars in one galaxy. That's a lot of stars! The galaxy to which our sun and solar system belong is called the Milky Way Galaxy. It has a spiral shape when viewed from space. From Earth, it looks like a "milky" band of white light.
The nearest spiral galaxy to the Milky Way Galaxy is called the Andromeda Galaxy. It is billions and billions of miles from the Milky Way Galaxy. There's that number billion again. You have probably heard of a million before. A million is a huge number. So what's a billion? It's one thousand million! It is safe to say that the Andromeda Galaxy is a long, long, long way away! Even so, it is sometimes possible to see the Andromeda Galaxy at night.

---

Scientists think there are billions of galaxies in the universe. There's that number billion again. There are billions of stars in each galaxy and billions of galaxies in the universe. That is almost more than you can think about!

## Passage:
Constellations
    
    
        Go outside one night and look up at the stars. There are billions of stars in our galaxy, but you can only see about 2,000 with your eyes. When you first look at them, they might just look like tiny dots of light.
Look a little closer at the night sky. You will see that some stars shine much brighter than others. Focus on the brightest stars first. Which ones really stand out to you? Then, look at the spaces between the bright stars. Ask yourself this question: "What would happen if I drew lines from one bright star to the next? What if I connected the dots like a puzzle? Would I see any shapes or patterns?"

---

Since ancient times, people have been studying the stars in the night sky. When ancient people looked up at the stars, they noticed that some stars seemed to be closer together. These groups of stars formed patterns and shapes.
One of the first people to describe these star patterns was a man named Ptolemy. He picked out the brightest stars and traced lines from one star to the next. He saw many different shapes and patterns. One group of stars looked like a bull. Another looked like a crab. A third looked like a bear. Ptolemy called these star patterns constellations. He found 48 constellations in total. Much later, 40 more constellations were added to Ptolemy's list. Today, astronomers say there are 88 constellations that can be seen in the night sky.

---

One famous constellation is called Ursa Major, which means Great Bear. Within Ursa Major, there are seven very bright stars that form a smaller group called the Big Dipper. Can you guess why it is called the Big Dipper? When you trace a line from star to star, the shape looks like a dipper. A dipper is like a big spoon you can use to scoop water. The stars on the left look like the handle. The stars on the right look like the scoop part.
Ptolemy also found another constellation called Ursa Minor, or Little Bear. This constellation is made up of seven stars too. Ursa Minor is also called the Little Dipper. The brightest star at the end of the handle has a special name. It is called Polaris.

---

Polaris is very special because it stays in the same place in the night sky all year long. Other stars move to different places in the sky during different times of the year, but Polaris does not move. Polaris sits almost directly over the North Pole of Earth. By finding Polaris, also called the North Star, you can figure out which direction is north. Then you can find all the other directions too. Long ago, sailors and explorers used this star to help them find their way when they traveled across oceans and land.
You can find Polaris the next time you look at the night sky. Start by looking for the Big Dipper first because it is easier to spot. Then, find the two "pointer" stars at the edge of the Big Dipper's scoop. Imagine there is a long arrow pointing the same way as these pointer stars. The first bright star you will see at the end of that arrow is Polaris, the North Star.

## Article: Exploring Space

## Passage:
Exploring Space
    
    
        People have wanted to study space for a very long time. Long ago, they could only see some stars and planets with their eyes. Since these objects were so far away, it was hard to see them clearly.
In 1609, a scientist named Galileo made a telescope to look at the night sky. His telescope made things look three times bigger than they really were. With his telescope, he found four moons that go around the planet Jupiter. He also looked at Saturn and the Milky Way.
After Galileo, scientists made bigger and better telescopes. Some telescopes are kept in special buildings called observatories on Earth. These observatories are often built on top of mountains, far from cities and bright lights. This helps scientists see the stars and planets more clearly.

---

Other telescopes are sent into space using rockets. These space telescopes can see much better than telescopes on Earth. One famous space telescope is the Hubble Telescope. NASA, the American group that studies space, launched it in 1990. The Hubble Telescope still flies around Earth today. It has sent back thousands of pictures to NASA. These pictures helped scientists learn that the universe is about 13 to 14 billion years old!
NASA has also sent rocket ships into space. At first, scientists thought it was too dangerous for people to go into space. They did not know what space travel would do to humans. So NASA first sent apes into space on rocket ships. Apes are mammals like humans, so scientists could learn about space travel by watching the apes. In 1961, NASA sent the first American astronaut into space. His name was Alan Shepard, and he stayed in space for only 15 minutes.

---

After 1961, NASA sent more manned flights into space. These manned flights had people inside who flew around Earth but did not land anywhere. Then in 1969, the United States sent a rocket ship called Apollo 11 to the moon.
Have you ever thrown a ball up in the air? The ball goes up first, then comes back down. No matter how hard you throw it, it always comes back down because of gravity. Gravity is a force of attraction that pulls things toward each other. Earth's gravity pulls the ball back down to the ground.

---

Earth's gravity makes it hard for rocket ships like Apollo 11 to fly into space. The rocket ship has to push up with a lot of force. It has to push up so hard that gravity cannot pull it back down. Apollo 11 used very strong rockets to lift off. It went up slowly at first, then got faster and faster. After just a few seconds, it shot up out of Earth's atmosphere and into outer space.

## Passage:
A Walk on the Moon
    
    
        Once Apollo 11 was up in space, the three astronauts had to steer it to the moon. Each astronaut had an important job to do. One astronaut was in charge of flying the main spaceship, called Columbia. The other two astronauts had to get into a smaller landing craft called the Eagle. Then, they had to steer the Eagle down to the moon's surface and land it safely.
The astronaut who had to steer the Eagle was named Neil Armstrong. He had to find a good, flat spot to land the craft. He also had to set the Eagle down very gently so it would not crash. Millions of people around the world tuned in to watch Armstrong and the Eagle on live television. At first, Armstrong had a hard time getting the Eagle to go where he wanted it to go. The landing was tricky and dangerous. But in the end, he landed it just fine.

---

Armstrong sent an exciting message back to Earth by radio: "The Eagle has landed!" The crowds watching on TV went wild with joy. They danced and sang in the streets. They shouted and waved the United States flag high in the air. For the first time ever in history, humans had landed on the moon! What happened next was even more amazing. The astronauts were going to walk on the moon!
There is no air for breathing on the moon. It is also very cold in space. So the astronauts could not just walk out in shorts and a T-shirt like they would on Earth. They had to put on special space suits to protect their bodies. They had to wear masks over their faces. They also had to carry heavy tanks full of air for breathing while they explored.

---

Armstrong went out of the Eagle first. He climbed down the steps of the landing craft until he was on the last step. Then, he made a little hop down to the surface. He landed on the moon and kicked up a small cloud of moon dust with his boots. Then, he said the famous words, "That's one small step for man, one giant leap for mankind." Soon, another astronaut named Buzz Aldrin joined Armstrong on the moon's surface.
Once again, people watching on television back on Earth cheered loudly. They were very proud that the United States had put the first men on the moon! While Armstrong and Aldrin were walking around on the moon, pilot Michael Collins stayed on the part of the spaceship that was still going around the moon in orbit.

---

Armstrong and Aldrin spent more than 21 hours on the moon. They found that it was easy to move around on the moon, which has much less gravity than Earth. They could jump up high and seemed to float down slowly like feathers. They used different tools to explore the moon's surface. They knew the scientists back on Earth were hoping to learn new things about the moon. They dug up samples of moon rocks and moon dirt to take back to Earth for study.
After exploring the moon, Aldrin and Armstrong got back inside the Eagle. They lifted off from the moon's surface and flew back up into space. They met up with Michael Collins on board the other part of the spaceship. Then, all three astronauts flew back to Earth together. The spaceship came speeding back from space and splashed down into the ocean. A Navy ship came to pick up the astronauts and take them safely back to NASA.

## Article: What’s it Like in Space?

## Passage:
What’s it Like in Space?
    
    
        Since Apollo 11, many more astronauts have traveled to space. Scientists have learned that Earth and space are very different places. One of the biggest differences is gravity. Gravity is a force that pulls things toward each other. On Earth, gravity is pretty strong. Even the best jumpers can only jump a few feet off the ground. Try it and see! If you want to jump high, you have to fight against gravity.
Remember when astronauts Aldrin and Armstrong walked on the moon? They could jump up high very easily. They didn't come down quickly either. Instead, they seemed to float down slowly. This happened because gravity on the moon is not as strong as on Earth. The moon is much smaller than Earth. So the force of gravity is weaker on the moon.

---

If you think that is cool, wait until you learn what happens out in space! When astronauts are far away from the moon or planets, they do not feel gravity at all. They and their spaceship move freely through space together. Since the astronaut and spaceship move freely together, the astronauts look and feel like they are floating in the air!
Up in space, lots of things work differently. You can do a flip and not worry about whether you will make it all the way around before you fall down! You could spin and turn in any direction you want.

---

Eating is very different in space too. When you eat lunch at school, your food stays where you put it. If you set it on a table, it stays there until you pick it up. Gravity holds it down. But if you were up in space, you and your food would be moving freely together. If you let go of your sandwich, it might drift away and float around the spaceship!
There are other big differences in space besides weak gravity. Do you remember that the astronauts on the moon had to carry tanks of air for breathing? Another way outer space is different from Earth is that there is no air or oxygen at all in space. The astronauts inside the spaceship don't need to carry air tanks. That's because oxygen is being pumped inside their spaceship so they can breathe.

---

Since there is no air in space, you also cannot hear sounds in outer space. Everything is completely quiet. It is also very cold in space. The astronauts must train for many months before going into space. They need to know what to expect and how to live in such a different place. Do you think you would like to go into space someday? It would be quite an adventure!

## Passage:
The Space Shuttle
    
    
        After Apollo 11 went to the moon, people wanted to learn more about space. Scientists called this exploration. Other astronauts went to the moon too. But scientists also wanted to explore other parts of space beyond the moon. It cost a lot of money and took a long time to build spaceships. Do you remember that when Apollo 11 came back from space, it landed in the ocean? It could not land safely on the ground, so this type of spacecraft always had to land in the sea. Once it landed in the ocean, this kind of spacecraft could never be used again.

---

In 1981, scientists built a new kind of spacecraft. It was called a space shuttle. This spacecraft was reusable, which means it could be used over and over again. The space shuttle could fly up into space and then zoom back down to Earth. When it came back to Earth, the pilot could land it on a runway just like an airplane. It glided down from space and landed on a runway, but the runway had to be very long.
The space shuttle flew back into space again and again. It moved back and forth between Earth and space like a bus. That is why it was called a shuttle. The space shuttle itself was the white part that looked like a jet plane. The other parts were called booster rocket pieces. The booster rocket parts helped the space shuttle get off the ground. They helped it fight against Earth's gravity. Once the space shuttle was up in space, it dropped the booster rocket parts because it did not need them anymore.

---

The space shuttle was also used to help build an amazing space station. A space station is like a house in space where astronauts can live for months at a time. The space shuttle carried supplies back and forth from Earth to the space station. It also gave astronauts a ride home to Earth when it was time for them to return. This was especially important because astronauts needed a safe way to get back home.

---

The last space shuttle mission happened in July 2011. NASA scientists and Americans were proud of everything the astronauts had done in thirty years. With the end of the space shuttle missions, NASA is planning other ways to explore space. Those plans include sending unmanned probes and satellite machines into space. A satellite is a machine that flies around Earth or other planets to take pictures and collect information. NASA scientists hope to learn more about the moon's gravity and are even talking about trying to explore asteroids!

The International Space Station
    
    
        Would you like to have a bedroom in outer space? Some astronauts do! The United States and other countries use the space shuttle to send astronauts to a special place called the International Space Station. This space station moves around Earth in a big circle. It is like a house floating in space. Three astronauts can live there at one time. They stay for six months before coming back to Earth.
The space station moves very far above our planet. It is so far up that the astronauts don't feel gravity like we do down here. Gravity is the force that pulls things down to Earth. When we lift our arms and legs on Earth, we have to work against gravity pulling us down. This is good for our bodies because it helps keep our muscles strong. But astronauts in space don't have gravity to work against. They float around instead of walking. This means they don't get much exercise just moving around. They have to run on a special machine at least once every day to keep their muscles strong and healthy.

---

Sleeping in space is very different from sleeping in your bed at home. The astronauts don't feel gravity, so they float freely inside the space station. This means they can sleep right side up, upside down, or sideways. It doesn't matter which way they face because there is no up or down in space! They have to zip themselves into sleeping bags that are attached to the walls. Otherwise, they would float away while they sleep. Do you think you would like sleeping while floating in the air?
Taking a shower in space is much harder than taking a shower at home. On Earth, water comes out of the shower head and falls down on your body because of gravity. Then the water runs off your skin and goes down the drain. But in space, water doesn't fall down at all! Instead, the water forms little floating bubbles. Astronauts have to catch the water and rub it on their skin with their hands. When they are done washing, the water doesn't drip off their bodies. They have to use special tools to scrape the water off their skin.

---

Astronauts must shower inside a small, closed room called a pod. This pod keeps all the water from floating away into the rest of the space station. If water bubbles floated around freely, they could cause big problems. The floating water might get into the computers and other important equipment. This could break the machines that keep the astronauts safe and healthy in space.
You can see that many things are different when people live in space instead of on Earth. That is why leaving the space station and coming back to our planet can be very hard for astronauts. It takes time for them to get used to living on Earth again. After spending months floating in space, they have trouble with Earth's gravity. Their arms and legs feel very heavy and hard to move. They find it difficult to stand up without falling over. They feel like they might tip over when they try to walk. But after a few weeks back on Earth, their bodies remember how to work with gravity. They begin to feel normal again. Sometimes when they look up at the night sky, they even feel a little homesick for their floating home in outer space.

Dr. Mae Jemison
    
    
        Do you know what a role model is? A role model is someone who shows others how to live a good life. Many kids look up to famous people like sports stars or singers. They see them on TV and want to be like them. But some of the best role models are people you might not see on TV. They work as doctors, teachers, or police officers. Some are scientists who study space. Mae Jemison is one of these special people.
Mae Jemison was born on October 17, 1956, in Decatur, Alabama. When she was little, her family moved to Chicago, Illinois. Mae always worked very hard in school. She loved science, but she also liked art and music. She was so smart that she finished high school when she was only 16 years old! Then she went to Stanford University in California. Most college students study just one thing because college is very hard. But Mae studied two different things and did great in both. She learned about chemical engineering and African-American studies.

---

After college, Mae went to medical school to become a doctor. She wanted to help people in Africa and other poor countries. So she joined the Peace Corps as a volunteer. In Africa, many people could not get good medical care. Mae helped sick people get better. She also taught other workers how to take care of patients. She worked very hard to make health care better in the places where she lived.
When Mae came back to the United States, she had a new dream. More than anything, she wanted to become an astronaut and fly into space. She decided to apply to NASA to join their astronaut program. But the first time she applied, NASA said no. Mae did not give up. She tried again, and this time NASA said yes! Only 15 people were chosen from 2,000 people who wanted to be astronauts. Mae was one of them!

---

Training to be an astronaut was very hard work. Mae had to get her body in great shape. She had to learn how to move when there is no gravity in space. She also had to study many books and pass difficult tests about space travel. Mae worked hard and passed all her tests.
In 1992, Mae was picked for a special mission on the Endeavour space shuttle. A big rocket shot the Endeavour up into space to fly around Earth. Mae became the first African-American woman astronaut to travel in space! Her job was to study how plants and animals act when they have no weight in space. Mae did experiments with another astronaut named Jan Davis. They collected important information for scientists at NASA to study. The mission was a huge success.

---

After her amazing trip to space, Mae stopped working at NASA. She became a teacher at Dartmouth College. There she shared her love of science and space with students. Mae also started her own company called The Jemison Group, Inc. Her company still works with people in poor countries today. They look for ways that science can make people's lives better. Mae Jemison is truly a role model that we can all look up to and admire!

## Article: Nicolaus Copernicus

## Passage:
Nicolaus Copernicus
    
    
        Do you remember learning that long ago, people thought the sun moved around Earth? This seemed to make sense to them. Each morning, the sun came up in the east. At the end of the day, the sun went down in the west. To explain this, people said the sun traveled around Earth. The Greeks and other ancient people believed this was true. But you also learned that this was not correct.
Around the same time that Christopher Columbus came to America, a man named Nicolaus Copernicus was studying math and space science at a school in Poland. He later moved to Italy where he also studied medicine and law. But Copernicus loved studying space the most. He knew that for a very long time, people believed that the sun moved around Earth.

---

Copernicus began to carefully watch and write down how the sun, planets, and stars moved. After much research, Copernicus decided that the old belief could not be true. His observations led him to believe the opposite! He realized that Earth was actually moving around the sun! He also believed that as Earth went around the sun, it also spun around completely each day.
All of Copernicus' ideas came from looking at space without any special tools to help him see better. He wrote down what he saw from a tall church tower. He also used math to help prove his ideas were right. Finally, Copernicus wrote a book explaining his new ideas about how space worked. Other scientists tried to prove him wrong, but they could not. Most were amazed by what he had discovered!

---

However, Copernicus' ideas were very different from what people had believed for thousands of years. People believed that Earth and humans were the center of everything in space. Many church teachings at that time were also based on this belief. Copernicus dared to suggest that Earth was not the center of everything. Instead, he said the sun was at the center! Many church leaders disagreed with Copernicus' ideas and spoke against them. So his beliefs were not accepted by most people while he was alive.
Even after Copernicus died, the church continued to argue against the idea that the sun was at the center. Some scientists agreed with Copernicus' ideas. A scientist named Galileo agreed with Copernicus and was punished and put in prison for a long time because of his beliefs.

---

Today we know that Copernicus was right. It took great courage to speak up and suggest an idea that was so different from what people had always believed. But that is how science works. Even today, scientists continue to learn new things about space and our universe. This means our knowledge is always changing and growing as we discover more about the world around us.

## Passage:
The Big Bang
    
    
        Have you ever wondered how the universe and our solar system came to be? Scientists called astronomers have studied space for thousands of years. During that time, people came up with many different ideas about how our solar system began.
With the help of telescopes, modern astronomers noticed something amazing. All of the distant galaxies in the universe seem to be moving outward. The galaxies that are farther away are moving outward even faster. Stars are moving away from Earth and so are whole galaxies. In 1929, a scientist named Edwin Hubble discovered this pattern. It is now called "Hubble's Law." This is the same "Hubble" after whom the Hubble Telescope is named!

---

Hubble's discovery led scientists to offer explanations of how the solar system started. There are many explanations about how the universe came to be. Scientists call these explanations theories. A theory in science tries to explain how something happened or how something works. One recent theory is known as the Big Bang Theory.
Three scientists who study space proposed the Big Bang Theory in the 1960s. These scientists are called astrophysicists. They use math to study the universe. George Lemaitre, Alexander Friedmann, and Edwin Hubble studied the ideas of another scientist named Albert Einstein. They used his ideas to develop their explanation of how the universe first started.

---

The Big Bang Theory suggests that long ago, the universe and everything in it was once a tiny ball. All of the stuff that makes the universe was squeezed together into one tiny space. This stuff is called matter. Imagine if all the planets and all the stars were squeezed together to fit in your hand. That is how tight and tiny the ball was!
Scientists think that everything began expanding outward about 14 billion years ago. All the matter in the universe exploded out at once! That is why the event is called the Big Bang. When all the matter in the ball began moving out, it was very hot. It was hotter than even the hottest star. Everything was moving so fast as it expanded that nothing could stick together. It was too hot and fast for anything to be like what it is today. There were no galaxies, no stars, no planets, and no people.

---

But over time the matter began to cool down. As the matter cooled and stopped moving so fast, gravity was able to hold little bits of matter together in round shapes called spheres. These little spheres, with the help of gravity, came together and became the first stars and galaxies. Over billions of years of matter moving and growing, the universe became the way it looks today. The sun and planets in our solar system formed about four billion years ago.
Scientists are continuing to look into space for more clues about the Big Bang. There is still a lot to learn about the early universe. Scientists sometimes make small changes to the Big Bang Theory to match what they have learned. It is amazing to think how old our solar system is and that scientists are still trying to find out how it all started!

## Article: Etu, the Hunter

## Passage:
Etu, the Hunter
    
    
        We walked quietly across the glistening snow. The sun made the snow sparkle and shine like stars in the night sky. Before we left our camp, my brothers told me many times that I must do exactly what they said. If I did not listen, they would send me away.
They said that as we walked, I must step quietly into my older brother's footprints. My oldest brother, Hakan, was six years older than me. He was the lead tracker. His footprints showed us the way. My brother Delsin was three years older than me. He followed closely behind Hakan, stepping easily into his footprints. I was right behind Delsin, trying hard not to wobble from side to side as I stepped into his big footprints.

---

My father and uncles moved in a straight line some distance behind us. These were the men in our family who hunted the great creatures that lived on our land. Each man held a flint-tipped spear and an atlati, which is a spear thrower. My brothers and I had our slingshots over our shoulders. This was my first hunt. We were following a herd of woolly mammoths. We were waiting for one member of the herd to fall behind the others.
As soon as one mammoth fell behind, the men would move forward and drive it into a ditch. We had to be very careful though. It was important that the creature did not know we were there. If it did, it would charge at us using its great size and curved tusks as powerful weapons. If this happened, the herd would panic and stampede for sure.

---

I loved listening to the sound of the crunching snow under our feet. I loved feeling the icy wind against my cheeks. All around us, the tips of tall, green grass came up from the snow-covered land. The woolly mammoths ate the grass. They used their tusks to push the snow aside so they could reach every part of it.
We walked until the sun began to sink in the sky and a golden haze touched the earth. I spotted different groups of tall grass that brought color to the mostly white terrain. As we walked, I thought about my mother and sister, who were also working. They were fixing the shelter we had built from mammoth skin, bones, branches, and earth. Several days earlier, strong winds had damaged our camp near the herd. They knew that mammoth flesh could feed many people for a long time. It could be dried and saved until the next successful hunt.

---

Suddenly, my brother Hakan stopped moving and raised his arm. Then, he told us to crouch down. We did exactly what he said. I looked around to see the men behind us doing the same thing. My brother put a finger to his lips and looked at us, telling us to be quiet. I could tell that he had spotted a lone woolly mammoth that had fallen behind the herd.
As we crouched down in the snow, the hunters began to move forward. I held my breath as my father and uncles moved past us. I knew that they would not use their spears until the giant creature was trapped in the ditch with no way out. My heart pounded as I watched the men surround what looked like a young mammoth. They drove it into the snow-covered ditch, shouting as they went. Then my father and uncles threw their spears. I watched this great and powerful creature fall to the ground.

## Article: Adoette and Awan, the Bird Chasers

## Passage:
Adoette and Awan, the Bird Chasers
    
    
        "Adoette, it's time to go," whispered Awan. "The sun is almost up!"
"I'm coming," Adoette replied softly as she walked through the doorway of her home. "I have fish for us to eat later."
"I have water for us to drink," Awan said as he smiled at Adoette.
The children began to chat with each other as they walked toward their family's cornfield. The cornfield was not far from their village near the river. As they walked, they heard crows making loud sounds. The crows would caw as they rose up into the warm spring air. The crows had come back to show that winter was over. The warmth of the sun was helping life grow in the sleeping Earth again.

---

After the corn was planted, the women and children made sure the young plants got plenty of water. If the spring rains did not come to water the earth, then the women and children did it themselves. They would use a hoe to dig small paths called channels to help water reach the plants. The children also had the important job of protecting the young plants from all kinds of hungry critters.
Adoette and Awan were sent to the family cornfield each day to guard the crop. The corn seeds had just been planted and needed time to germinate, or start growing. Crows were the worst enemy during this time. They would either dig up the newly planted seeds with their sharp talons, or they would wait for the seeds to start growing. Then they would pull up each small plant and eat the corn seed, leaving the rest behind.

---

As the two children arrived in the cornfield, they could see several crows were already there. The crows sat in the dirt, watching the young plants with their dark eyes. Adoette and Awan placed their supplies on the ground and yelled at the crows. The crows stared at the children, then flapped their wings and flew away toward the horizon. One crow, however, could not lift its body off the ground. Instead, it tried to scuttle away from the children, moving quickly along the ground toward some low bushes.
"Oh, it's hurt!" said Adoette. "We must help it."
"Help it!" said Awan loudly. "We're supposed to chase it away."
"If it can't fly, other animals might hurt it," Adoette continued.
"You are crazy," said Awan.

---

Slowly, Adoette made her way toward the crow. The crow had stopped moving in front of a bush. It turned to look at Adoette. She began to crouch down low to get closer to the bird.
"Are you hurt?" Adoette asked the bird softly. "Here, let me help you."
The crow moved under the bush and stared at Adoette. She sat down in the dirt and talked with the crow for a while. Awan was not happy with his cousin's behavior, so he walked away to look for other things. After some time, Adoette reached under the bush and gently picked up the bird. The crow flapped its wings for a moment, but then settled down peacefully in Adoette's arms.
When Awan came back, he found Adoette watching the field with a crow in her arms. She seemed to command the bird's trust completely.
"What are you going to do with it?" asked Awan, who was surprised to see his cousin holding their enemy.
"I'm going to make it better," Adoette said happily. "Then we can store it safely until it can fly again."
Awan shook his head. For the rest of the day, the two children guarded the corn crop that would later grow tall and produce ears covered in green husks. When the sun began to set, they walked back to the village. Adoette walked proudly beside Awan, carrying the enemy-turned-friend in her arms.

## Passage:
Akando and Aponi, the Gatherers
    
    
        I looked up at the blue sky and had to squint because it was so bright. The sun was very hot that day. There were no clouds anywhere in the sky. The leaves on the trees were changing to beautiful autumnal colors that made me want to stop and look at them. But the heat from the sun would still linger in the air. I stood still for a moment to rest my tired feet. I could tell that the hot day would soon change into a big thunderstorm.
I looked back toward our village, but I could barely see it now. I couldn't see the roofs of the houses or the smoke coming up from each family hearth. But I could still see our chief's home in the distance. I could also see the ceremonial buildings that sat on top of the large mounds that my people would construct for important meetings.

---

My twin brother Akando and I had been sent out with our baskets to gather wild fruits, berries, and nuts. This was the time of year when most children in our village had to work hard. We gathered nuts, fruits, and berries that could be dried to preserve them for later. We also collected wild onions and milkweed. This food would be very important when winter came and the earth was frozen. We had to gather everything that nature gave us before the rains washed it away or the cold killed the plants.
The crops we grew in our fields were also being gathered. We grew sunflowers, corn, squash, and tobacco. Some of the older children were helping in the fields. Only the Shamans were allowed to gather tobacco and the special roots and bark used for medicine. My brother told me that the Shamans offered tobacco to the four directions before taking the medicine plants.

---

I looked ahead to find Akando. My brother was so far ahead that I was losing sight of him. "Akando, slow down!" I called. "Can we rest for a while?" Akando looked back at me. Even though we are twins and the same size, he is stronger than I am. He had a large birch bark basket around his waist. It was almost full to the rim with hickory nuts and hazelnuts. My basket was smaller and only half full with butternuts and acorns.
"Just for a short time, Aponi," he called back. "We haven't even started collecting berries yet." Akando walked back and sat down next to me. "Want to play a game?" he asked. I said yes eagerly. He placed three large autumnal oak leaves on the ground and hid a stone under one of them. I had to guess which leaf hid the stone.

---

We played the guessing game three times, and Akando won most of the rounds like always. "Now let's go," he said. "The sooner we gather everything, the sooner we can go home." I didn't want to get up yet. "Later, I will show you how to beat me in the guessing game," Akando said, trying to get me moving. That worked! "Really?" I asked, jumping up and grabbing my basket. "Really!" he replied. "But first you have to fill that basket!" I smiled and took my brother's hand. Together we walked under the beautiful canopy of red, gold, and copper-colored leaves.

## Article: Alemeda, the Basket Weaver

## Passage:
Alemeda, the Basket Weaver
    
    
        "Alemeda! Where are you?" my mother called out.
I did not answer. Instead, I crept around the corner of our home and hid in the shade. I waited and watched quietly. I held my breath and was about to close my eyes when a lizard ran across my bare feet. It tickled!
"She's hiding from you," my younger brother Kele said. "She's over there," he pointed at me.
I stuck my tongue out at Kele. He was always getting me into trouble with our mother.
"Alemeda, we need you. We have work to do. We must finish the baskets," my mother said as I walked toward her. She was not angry, but I could tell she would not let me play. I had important work to do.

---

I walked slowly to the shaded area that my father had built from wooden poles and coverings. I kicked at the dirt as I walked. There were several of these structures around our village. Women sat under them weaving baskets of different shapes and sizes. They also made a host of other useful things. Men sat together making tools for hunting and farming.
All the women in our village made baskets. Baskets were very important because people used them for carrying water, storing grain, fruits, nuts, and berries, and even for cooking food.
"Sit near me," my grandmother said as I stood beside her.
I sighed deeply and sat down on the ground next to her. She smiled and handed me the basket I had started making the day before.
"Our people have been making these baskets since time began," she explained. "This skill has been passed down from one generation to the next. It is important that you learn it, Alemeda."

---

"Really?" I asked, looking at her wise, old face. "Then why are you making me do it?"
Grandmother looked at me for a few moments. Then she asked, "When you hunt, fish, or farm, what will you do with the food you find?"
"Eat it!" I said happily.
"But we can't eat everything at once," she laughed. "We must save the corn we grow. We must dry some of the meat we hunt. We must store the fruits and berries we gather. We need to keep this food safe so we can survive when winter comes. You will see, Alemeda, how important it is to learn this skill."
"Now remember what I told you yesterday. All coiled baskets are made from plants that bend easily. Plants like yucca, split willow, rabbitbrush, or skunkbrush work the best."

---

"I remember," I said, still thinking I would rather be hunting. "Is that why we can make rope, sandals, mats, and clothes from these plants too?"
"Yes, these plants have many uses. But it is our skill as weavers that helps us make these things. The copper color of some baskets comes from certain plant dyes we use," she said with a big smile.
"Plus, Alemeda, you want to get married someday, don't you?" she asked with a grin.
"No," I replied quickly.
My grandmother laughed loudly. "Well, in case you change your mind, your weaving skills might get you noticed by those boys you like to hunt with."
"Yuck," I said, and spat in the dirt to show what I thought about that idea.
"Well, just in case, we better get to work," Grandmother said with a chuckle. Then together we began to weave the baskets that my people had been making since time began.

## Article: Alo, the Spirit Giver

## Passage:
Alo, the Spirit Giver
    
    
        Hello! My name is Alo. I am a ten-year-old Hopi boy. Welcome to my village in the desert. It snowed last night, but not very much. The snow only came up to my feet. The warm morning sun melted it all away quickly. My younger brothers and sisters wanted to play in the snow. They were sad to see it disappear so fast into the dry ground.
Today is a very important day for my people. Today is the Bean Dance Ceremony. The spirits, or as my people call them, kachinas, have come to Earth. They left their home on the tall mountains on the darkest day of the year. That was several weeks ago. They will stay with us until the longest day of summer. They watch over us and protect us. Long ago, they lived here on Earth and taught us how to hunt, gather food, and farm. Then they left us but promised to return for half of each year.

---

The word kachina means 'father of life'. We live in the hot, arid desert lands of our forefathers. We could not survive here without help from the spirits. Kachinas care for every living thing on Earth. All living things go to the spirit world when they die. Kachinas are the spirits of everything that has ever lived. They control the moon, the stars, the thunder, and our crops. They also watch over our health. Many of the kachinas are our ancestors who became cloud spirits that bring us rain.
On special days, the kachinas take us into the spirit world. Today is one of those days and I will finally make that journey. I will take part in the Bean Dance Ceremony. This is one of our most important ceremonies. Today, the people of my village will ask the spirits to help us prepare the earth for planting. We will ask especially for rain. I have given many prayer feathers and corn seeds to the spirits to get ready for this ceremony.

---

On days like today, boys from age ten to the elders in our village wear special kachina clothing and face masks. Only boys and men can do this. The special clothing and masks represent spirits. When we wear the special clothing and masks in these ceremonies, we actually become those spirits.
If you come to the ceremony, watch for the Aholi Kachina spirit. That is the Hopi rain spirit. The boys and men who become that spirit will wear colorful cloaks and may carry special sticks. They will wear bright blue masks or headdresses. They will hold rattles made from gourds. When they shake the rattles, it sounds like rain falling. Often, within hours of the ceremony, rain will actually begin to fall.

---

I will not be asking for rain though. My father is very sick, so today I will become the Bear Kachina. The Bear Kachina can heal sick people. When I become that spirit, I will make my father well again. If you come to the ceremony, you will know me by my mask that has bear paw prints on both cheeks.
This is my first time in such an important ceremony and I must do my best. I must heal my father. This year he was too sick to make the kachina dolls for my sisters. My uncle had to make them instead. We need him to be well again soon. My brothers and sisters want to play with him. I want to help him prepare the fields and plant and harvest the beans and corn we grow each year. The sap from the corn stalks will flow again when spring comes, and father must be well to help with the harvest.

        "Flo, I'll race you to that tree over there," said Meda. She pointed to one of the maple trees.
"Okay," I said with confidence. I was one of the fastest runners among the girls my age in our village. I wondered why Meda wanted to race me at all.
Right away, Meda flew like an arrow straight toward the tree. She hoped that a quick start would help her beat me. But like a shooting star across the night sky, I caught up to her quickly. Just before we reached the tree, I passed her and touched the trunk first.
"I won," I said happily. "You're pretty fast though, Meda. You are a year younger than me, so that was a good race!"
"Yes! Next year when we come back to the maple tree forest, I'll be able to beat you," Meda said with a big smile.
I smiled back. "I'll still be a year older than you," I said.
"I know. You'll always be older. But I think that next year, I will be taller than you," she said like it was a fact.
"Well, we'll see about that," I replied as I looked at her feet. They were already bigger than mine and she was only a little bit shorter than me. I thought she might be right, but I wasn't going to say so.

---

This was my favorite time of year. It was when the eagles built their spring nests. The chickadees made their strange, eerie call in the early morning. The snow was melting everywhere and tree buds were starting to emerge every day.
This was also when my family came to camp in the maple tree forest. My uncles and aunts and their children came too. We did this every year at the beginning of spring. We left our summer and winter village and returned to our forest camp. In the fall we camped near the fields where we grew our crops.
We always came back to the same maple forest camp. It was a good-sized clearing surrounded by many maple trees and birch trees. We returned here each year to collect sap from the maple trees and turn it into sweet syrup that we all loved.
This year we were lucky. The winter winds and snow had not broken our wigwam frames from the previous year. We only had to wrap the deerskin around the frames. After we made our campfire, the children could play before the real work started.

---

Once we were settled, the men used their axe to make small, deep cuts in the maple tree trunks. Then we waited for the sap to trickle out. As it did, the women and children would funnel the sap into birch baskets or clay pots. We used curved pieces of cedar wood or hollow sumac stems to guide the sap.
Sap from the maple tree looks like water when it first comes out of the tree. After the sap is collected, my mother and aunts cook it in a clay pot. Sometimes they put the pot right on the open campfire. Other times they put red-hot rocks into the clay pots. After cooking it for a while, the sap becomes sweet syrup. If you keep cooking it, the sap turns into sugar.
During this time, the older girls also collect birch bark. They strip the bark from trees and pound it until it can be shaped into storage containers or dishes. The men and boys spend their time hunting and fishing. In the evening, we all gather around the campfire to share stories.

---

"Come on, Flo," yelled Meda, who had walked away to watch the men work. "I can smell dinner cooking."
She was right. The delicious smell of deer meat floated up into the cool evening air.
"Race you back," I said. This time I took off like an arrow shot from my father's bow.

## Article: Yutu, the Dog Trainer

## Passage:
Yutu, the Dog Trainer
    
    
        "Come here, Miki," I called. Miki had been the runt of the litter. He was the smallest puppy when he was born. He had been puny and sick for the first weeks of his life. My father was sure that he would die. I fed him and kept him warm. Sometimes I would sneak him into my cozy bed at night. I gave him the Inuit name for small.
Miki wagged his tail and ran toward me. He moved quickly and seemed to scamper across the snow. Then, he flopped down right on my feet and rested his head on the snow.
When Miki's brothers and sisters were old enough to be weaned from their mother, my father began to train them to be sled dogs. My people, the Inuit, are expert dog sled trainers. That's because we live in a land that is frozen for a large part of the year. So, we rely a lot on our dogs to help us travel and hunt.

---

Inuit sled dogs have to be strong and fast. When Miki was younger, he was neither of these things. Sled dogs have to pull heavy loads and travel across long distances as speedily as they can. We Inuit live by our wits. We hunt and fish across this frozen land. We travel across the snow and ice in our sleds. We craft these sleds from bones or antlers, seal hide, and even frozen salmon skin. We build snow homes made from blocks of snow as we go.
Our dogs have to be able to sniff out seal breathing holes. They must stand firm with the other dogs when they come across a polar bear. The smell of danger can waft through the cold air, and our dogs must be ready. I couldn't imagine Miki doing any of these things, but he would have to. My father had made it clear that he would have to earn his keep.

---

I had grown up watching my father train the dogs. There are different ways to hitch the dogs so that they can pull the sleds. Often they are tied in pairs to a single towline. In deep snow, sometimes it is better to have the dogs pull the sled in a single line. This way, they can make a path through the snow.
The dogs are built to live in this frozen land better than people are. They have thick, waterproof fur coats. Their ears are extra furry to prevent frostbite. Their paws are large and have thick pads with fur. Even when we strip away layers of ice from their fur, they stay warm. After a long day of work, they enjoy succulent pieces of fresh fish and meat.

---

Once Miki was strong enough, I began to train him. At first, I worked with him on basic commands. Then, I put a harness on him and had him pull small loads across the snow. The very first time he had to pull something, he raced off like an arctic fox. He thought we were playing a game. He soon learned to pull like I needed him to, though. He was also very fast.
My father had watched me as I trained Miki. I think even he was surprised by how well Miki learned. Today was the day that he would leave me. He was going with my father and uncles on a hunting trip. I bent down and patted Miki on the head. "Be good, Miki. Do what you are told," I said to him. Miki looked right at me and wagged his tail. Then, my father came and led him away.

## Passage:
Salali, Dustu, and the Festival of Hope
    
    
        "It's time you two lazy lizards did some work," came the sound of my grandmother's voice. "There is a lot to do before we go to the festival."
"Okay, Grandmother," I replied. "I will go help mother prepare the food for the feast."
"What will you do?" asked my grandmother, as she turned to face Dustu. "Do you have a plan?"
Dustu shook his head and looked glum.
"Well, I will give you one. I would like you to get small branches for the campfire. Now run along."
Dustu knew better than to argue with her. His obedience to grandmother was always complete. He reached for his axe and began to walk away. I knew he would make his way to the forest edge.

---

"Oh, can I go with him to help him carry the wood?" I offered. Dustu was my younger brother and I did not like it when he went into the forest alone.
"Dustu, wait for me," I called, as I chased after him. He turned to me, grinned, and then started to run.
We reached the edge of the forest at the same time. Promptly, Dustu began to chop down small, slender branches and I began to gather them up. I worked to harness all the wood together in bundles.
"Are you excited about the ceremony?" I asked. "I can't wait to see the dancing!"
"I guess," he said, sounding sad again.
"What's wrong, Dustu?" I asked. "Usually you are even more excited than I am about the ceremony."
Dustu was silent. He just kept chopping small branches off the trees sulkily.

---

Eventually, he sat down on the grass beneath a row of birch trees and began to attack the earth with his axe.
"Why?" I asked, surprised.
"I pushed Elan in the river and he can't swim," he replied, with a serious look on his face.
"Why did you do that?" I asked, shocked.
"He's always calling me names," he replied, his face turning red as he spoke.
"Well Dustu, if you have to apologize, this is the best time of year to do so," I replied. This was indeed an important time of year. The people of our village had been busily preparing for the Green Corn Festival. During the Festival, we Cherokees celebrate our first corn crop. We prepare for this special event by cleaning our homes and our village. We make new clothes, pots, and baskets. People say they are sorry to anyone they might have offended. We give thanks to the sun for providing us with everything we need. It is thought of as a new beginning. Both my brother and I had already received our cleansing washes and we had fasted too.

---

Eventually, when we had more wood than we could comfortably carry, we walked back toward the village.
"I can't wait until the ceremony begins," I announced. "Tonight is the night of the full moon. At the campfire gathering, the leaders will announce who is getting married. Later, we will have our big feast."
"Okay, I've had enough. What do I have to do for you to smile again?" I asked. I was determined to make Dustu feel happy again before the festivities began.
"Well, Salali, there is one thing," he said at last. "Promise me that you won't ever marry Elan."
"What?" I yelled. "That will make you happy?"
"Yep!" said Dustu.
"It's a deal. I promise that I won't marry Elan," I said seriously.
"Good!" said Dustu. "That makes me very happy!" Little did Dustu know that I planned to one day marry Elan's brother. Even in the cold arctic winter or the hot summer, this was a basic promise I could keep easily.

The Hunting of the Great Bear: An Iroquois Tale
    
    
        Long ago, there were four brothers who were all good hunters. One day, during the cold time when frost covers the ground, a messenger came to their village.
"We need your help," said the messenger. "A great bear has come to live in our forest. It comes into our village at night too."
The four hunters did not say a word. They picked up their spears and called to their dog. Then they went with the messenger to help the other village.
On the way, they saw that the forest was very quiet. They also saw deep scratches on a pine tree. The great bear had made these marks when it stood up tall to rear on its back legs. The bear did this to mark its territory and show other animals that this was its home. The tallest brother held up his spear to try to touch the highest scratch marks, but he could not reach them.

---

"This bear has magic powers," said the second brother with fear.
"Don't worry," said the tallest brother. "The bear's magic will not work on us if we find its tracks first."
"Yes, that is true," said the third brother. "If we find Nyah-gwaheh's tracks and follow them, then it must run from us."
"This sounds like hard work," said the fourth brother, who was chubby and lazy. "Do we have any food?" he asked. His brothers did not answer him.
When the brothers entered the village, everything was very quiet. Only the village leader was there to meet them.
"We have come to help you," said the first brother.
"Pay no attention to him," the oldest brother would urge when the fourth brother kept asking for food. "We will find this great bear."
"I hope you can," said the village leader solemnly. "When we follow the great bear's tracks, they disappear."
"Do not worry," said the second brother. "Four Eyes can track anything, anywhere." Four Eyes was their dog. He had two black circles on his head, one above each eye.

---

The four brothers followed Four Eyes as he sniffed the ground. They could all feel that Nyah-gwaheh was close by. It was important to find its tracks before it began to follow them.
The fourth brother felt very hungry. He took out his pemmican pouch. He opened the bag and reached inside. Instead of food, he found nothing but worms. Nyah-gwaheh had used magic to change his food into worms.
Like a monstrous ghost, Nyah-gwaheh moved through the forest. It was planning to sneak up behind them.
Suddenly, Four Eyes lifted his head and barked loudly.
"We have found you," the first brother would proclaim.
Nyah-gwaheh began to run. The brothers followed. The great bear ran across valleys and hills. As they ran, day turned to night. Higher and higher they climbed up a mountain.
The fourth brother grew weary and tired. He pretended to fall and hurt his ankle. Two brothers had to carry him while the other carried his spear.

---

The great bear began to get tired too. Four Eyes got close enough to bite its tail.
"You can put me down now," said the fourth brother, who was nicely rested. When his brothers put him down, he began to sprint as fast as he could. He ran ahead of his brothers. Soon, the fourth brother was close enough to kill the bear with his spear.
When the three brothers caught up, he had already built a fire. "Sit down. I hope you are as hungry as I am," said the fourth brother, smiling. Together, they cooked and ate the bear meat.
"Brothers," said the first brother, looking down at his feet. "We are not on a mountain. We are high up in the sky." He was right. The magical bear had led them up into the heavens.
Suddenly, Four Eyes began to bark. The great bear was coming back to life! It began to stagger away, weak but moving. The brothers grabbed their spears and chased it across the sky.
And so it remains today. Each autumn, when people have festivities to celebrate the season, the brothers chase the bear across the sky. When they catch it, blood drips down to Earth and colors the maple leaves red. When they cook the bear, fat drips down and makes the grass pale.

## Passage:
Crow Brings the Daylight: An Inuit Myth
    
    
        Long ago, when the world was new, the Inuit people lived in darkness. They did not know what daylight was like. It was Crow who first told them about daylight. Even then, they did not believe him. Crow knew about daylight because he traveled back and forth between the north and the south. The Inuit people asked to hear about daylight over and over. The young boys and girls were very interested in what Crow said.
"How wonderful it would be if we had daylight," said one boy. "It would make hunting much easier." The Inuit people grew tired of just hearing about daylight. They wanted daylight for themselves and begged Crow to bring it to them.
"I can't do that," said Crow. "I am old now and no longer strong enough to travel so far." The Inuit children pleaded with Crow to do this one thing for them. Finally, Crow agreed to travel south.

---

Crow flew for miles and miles through the darkness that covered the lands of the north. He became tired but continued his journey. Soon, Crow saw a tiny rim of light far off in the distance. He knew that daylight was not far away.
All of a sudden, daylight appeared all around Crow. He found himself in a world of light and vibrant colors. Crow knew that his journey was over and he came to rest on the branch of a tree. He felt the warmth of the sun on his wings. When he opened his eyes again, he saw that the tree was just outside a village. Near the village was a long, winding river. Crow watched as a young girl used a bucket to collect water from the river.
Crow decided to follow the girl. He turned himself into a tiny speck of dust. Then, he floated down to settle in the girl's fur cloak.

---

It was nice and warm inside the snow lodge. Crow, disguised as a speck of dust, peeped out from inside the girl's hood. He saw a box that seemed to glow around the edges. "This must be daylight," thought Crow to himself. Crow had a plan. He floated into the ear of a small boy who was playing by himself. The boy rubbed his ear and then began to cry. His ear had started to hurt. His grandfather, who was the chief of the village, came running to find out what was wrong.
"Don't cry," said his grandfather. Crow, who was still inside the boy's ear, whispered to him: "You want to play with a ball of daylight." The boy repeated the words. The boy's grandfather asked his daughter to bring the glowing box to him. When she did, he reached inside and removed a glowing ball. Then, he tied it with string and handed it to the boy.
However, Crow scratched at the boy's ear and he began to cry again. "What is wrong?" asked the boy's grandfather. "You would like to play outside," whispered Crow. Once again, the boy repeated Crow's words. "Off you go then," said his grandfather.

---

The boy ran out of the snow lodge. Right away, Crow left the boy's ear and turned back into his feathered self. Then, quick as a flash, he swooped down and grabbed the string with his beak. Crow pulled the glowing ball away from the boy and flew up into the blue sky.
After a long while, the Inuit people caught sight of a ray of light. The light grew brighter and brighter. Finally, they saw their old friend Crow flying towards them. The Inuit people jumped for joy. Crow dropped the ball of light and it spread across their land. The light chased away the darkness. The sky became a brilliant blue and the snow glistened and sparkled in the sunlight.
"There is one thing you must know," Crow said seriously. "Daylight will not last forever. I was only able to take one ball of daylight. This ball of light will need to rest for six months each year. While it is resting, darkness will return." "We do not mind," said a young Inuit girl. "Having light for half of the year is better than a whole year of darkness. Thank you, Crow. You are our hero." Crow bowed his head.

## Passage:
The Lure of Spices
    
    
        When news spread about what Columbus had found, men from all over Spain raced to find treasure. Spanish conquistadors, like Francisco Vasquez de Coronado, were soldiers who set out to find silver and gold. They would slash their way through thick swamps with their swords. They marched across hot deserts. They explored and took over many new lands. A few years later, other countries from Europe got involved too. John Cabot was an explorer who went searching for England. Henry Hudson explored for England and for the Netherlands. Samuel de Champlain explored for France. These brave explorers changed the world forever. They connected Europe with the Americas.
Many European explorers hoped to find gold and other precious metals. You can probably understand why explorers wanted to find gold so badly. Gold is still valuable today. But you might be surprised to learn that many explorers were also excited about finding spices. You might be thinking, "Spices? Really? Why were they so eager to find spices?"

---

Here's the answer: Things that are scarce, or hard to find, cost a lot of money. That's why gold is expensive today. That's also why spices were so costly five hundred years ago. Back then, spices were very hard to find in Europe. So they cost lots of money. Some spices were almost worth their weight in gold!
The red balls you see in spice pictures are red peppercorns. A cook can add a few whole peppercorns to soup. He can use a special tool to grind the peppercorns into tiny pieces. Either way, the pepper will add flavor to the soup. It will make the soup taste spicier and better. White peppercorns come from the same plants as red ones. But the outer hull of the red peppercorn gets removed. This shows the inner kernel, which is white.

---

Cloves are another important spice. They are dried flower buds that add flavor to meats, stews, and even pumpkin pie. Cloves are very strong. Cooks must be careful because adding too many cloves can overwhelm the other flavors in their food. Peppercorns cannot be grown in Europe. They can only grow in warm, wet places like India. Today, we can get peppercorns from India pretty easily. An airplane or ship can bring large amounts to us. You can go to any grocery store and buy almost any spice you want.
Five hundred years ago, Europeans were not so lucky. The world was not connected like it is today. Spices were hard to get and move from place to place. A person in Spain who wanted pepper would have to pay much more than just the cost of the pepper. He would have to pay for shipping the pepper over land all the way from India using donkeys, mules, and camels.

---

It was the same with cloves and cinnamon. These plants could not grow in Europe. They had to be brought in from faraway places. The part of the cinnamon plant we use is the bark from the tree. Workers cut strips of bark off the tree. They cut away the outer bark and keep the inner bark. Then they roll it up like little scrolls to make cinnamon sticks. Cinnamon can also be ground up into powder, just like pepper. Getting funding for these long trips to find spices was hard work, but the profits made it worth the effort.
Do you like the taste of cinnamon? How much do you like it? Would you sail across an ocean to get cinnamon? In a way, that is exactly what European explorers were trying to do!
