## Passage:
Natural Changes to the Environment
    
    
        Ecosystems can be fragile. It doesn't take much to cause big changes in the environment. Sometimes the ecosystem can recover from a change. Sometimes the change lasts forever.
One common force of nature is when land wears away. Over time, the land on both sides of a stream can erode. When it rains really hard, a little stream can fill with water and flood. A flood may last for an hour. It may last for a few days.
Plants on a hillside have roots that reach deep into the soil. The roots hold the soil together. When it rains, or when the wind blows really hard, the plant roots hold the soil in place. Without plants, the soil starts to erode.

---

Water is one of nature's most powerful forces. During a big flood, the entire landscape can be changed. A flooded river can tear apart plants, trees, and soil. First, the topsoil is removed. This is the richest soil, where you find most of the nutrients and matter that is starting to decay. Once the topsoil is washed away, the forces of nature slowly eat away at the clay and rock underneath.
There is a place called Petrified Forest National Park in Arizona. Throughout the park, there are ancient trees that have turned to stone. The trees have been petrified! These may look like normal rocks, but they're not! There was a forest ecosystem here about 200 million years ago. This was during prehistoric times, when some of the first dinosaurs walked on Earth. These rocks are actually pieces of very old trees!

---

Back then, there were plants, animals, and tiny living things that helped matter decay. Scientists have found fossils in the Petrified Forest. These show that there were swamp plants, like ferns. There were also dinosaurs that looked sort of like crocodiles.
At some point, the area was flooded by huge amounts of water and mud. The trees were covered completely. The entire forest was destroyed, along with the food chain. All that mud covering the trees dried up. Over millions of years, the mud turned to rock. Instead of rotting away, the trees turned to rock, too!

---

Millions of years and countless floods later, the land in Petrified Forest National Park has worn away. We are left with this strange landscape. It is still called a forest, but many of the trees are really rocks. The land is almost like a desert now. However, the Petrified Forest does get some rain. There is actually a lot happening in this ecosystem, even though it looks like a dry, sandy place.
There are 500 different types of plants in Petrified Forest National Park. There are no dinosaurs, but there are little lizards. There are also toads, snakes, birds, and jackrabbits. Coyotes are near the top of the food chain. They eat just about anything, meat and plants alike. The Petrified Forest shows how nature's forces can change the landscape. When the land changes, the ecosystem changes too. There were once forests and swamps here. Now, it is a rocky desert. But it is still an ecosystem! Through all the changes, there has always been life here. Living things find a way to survive, even when they face extinction.

## Passage:
Human Changes to the Environment
    
    
        Every plant and animal in nature needs other living things to survive. A butterfly needs flowers for food. At the same time, flowers need butterflies to spread their pollen from plant to plant.
Long ago, early humans were part of nature too. They hunted animals and gathered plants for food. They made homes and clothes from things they found around them. Most importantly, they only used what they needed to stay alive.
But humans were different from other animals. They could make and use technology. At first, they made simple tools from stone and wood. These tools helped them hunt better and build stronger shelters.

---

Over time, technology got much better. Humans learned to make machines. Instead of hunting wild animals, they learned to raise cows and chickens for food. Instead of gathering berries and nuts, they learned to grow their own crops. Humans learned to change and control parts of nature to meet their needs.
With technology, humans could change the environment in countless ways. A wheat field may have once been a forest or grassland. Insects and other living things still live in the soil and eat the wheat plants. But this is not a natural field anymore. Humans planted the seeds and decide when to harvest the crops.
Every town and city was once a natural place where many species of plants and animals lived. Then humans used technology to change these natural places. There are still some trees and flowers in cities, but only because people put them there. Some animals like squirrels and birds learned to live in cities with humans.

---

Today, with all our cities and technology, we sometimes forget about nature. We think of nature as something we can visit, not something we are part of. We think of nature as a resource we can use and change however we want.
The Hoover Dam shows how people can change nature. This huge dam was built across the Colorado River. The dam can generate hydroelectric power, or electricity, for over a million people. The reservoir created by the dam gives water to thousands of homes and farms. The river is the source of this water and power.
The Hoover Dam helps people, but it also changed the river forever. It changed how the river flows and put several species of fish and plants in danger. Some of these species became endangered, which means they might disappear completely. The dam was good for people but not good for the environment.

---

Not all changes that humans make are bad for nature. People can live good lives while still protecting the balance of nature. A small town surrounded by forests shows this. People have their houses and roads, but most of the land around them still belongs to nature. Even a jackrabbit can find safe places to live near the town.
People use nature primarily to meet their needs, but we can learn to do this without hurting the environment. We can protect the countless species that share our world while still using natural resources wisely.

## Passage:
Environmental Damage Caused by Humans
    
    
        Most vehicles you see every day need gasoline to work. Cars, boats, trains, and planes all use gasoline for energy. When a car's engine burns gasoline, it makes the car move. Gasoline comes from oil, which is a thick, black liquid found deep underground in certain places on Earth.
Getting oil out of the ground is very hard work. People drill deep wells into the earth. These wells pump oil up from underground. Thousands of oil wells around the world are used to get oil from deep in the ground.
Much oil is located deep beneath ocean waters. Workers use a special platform called an oil rig. The oil rig floats far out in the ocean. Dozens of workers live on the oil rig for months at a time. They use special drills to get oil from hundreds or thousands of feet beneath the ocean surface.

---

Unfortunately, drilling for oil is difficult and dangerous. This danger became real on April 20, 2010, when a terrible accident happened. An oil rig called the Deepwater Horizon was working in the Gulf of Mexico, about 40 miles off the coast of Louisiana. An important piece of equipment deep underwater broke. This allowed oil and natural gases to escape from the earth. The escaping gases caused a huge explosion on the oil rig.
The Deepwater Horizon was destroyed by the explosion and fire. Sadly, 11 men died in the explosion and 16 others were badly hurt. But this was not the end of the story. The disaster that followed was a massive oil spill.
When the rig exploded, oil began flowing freely from inside the earth. Because it was so far underwater, nobody knew how to stop the oil. Within days, the waters near the damaged well were heavily polluted with thick, black oil. Oil continued to spill into the water for three months, and the oil quickly spread across the ocean.

---

The ocean ecosystem is fragile. Everything from tiny organisms to plants and fish need clean water to survive. The oil threatened fish and all other life in the nearby waters. Within days, oil from the oil spill washed up all along the Gulf Coast of the United States. The oil reached beaches in Texas, Louisiana, Mississippi, Alabama, and Florida. The oil threatened the lives of fish, birds, and other wildlife in or near the water.
The grassy, shallow wetlands along the Gulf Coast are home to a fragile ecosystem with a huge variety of wildlife. People were especially worried about the effect oil might have on this area. In the wetlands, you can find shellfish like oysters, crabs, and shrimp. Many birds live there, including herons, pelicans, and egrets. Reptiles such as alligators and snakes also live in the Gulf Coast wetlands. All of these animals can be harmed if they get covered in oil or eat other animals covered in oil.

---

The wetlands are very important for people too. They provide seafood like the shrimp you might eat in a restaurant. The wetlands are important for other reasons as well. The grass roots keep sand and soil in place. If the grasses get covered in oil, they could die. Then the sand and soil would wash away. As a result, the coastline could erode, which would harm nearby towns and cities.
Oil from the oil spill was a threat to life at sea and on land, including people. This was a huge problem, and everyone knew something had to be done to protect the wetlands and wildlife from the oil. People worked hard to save the Gulf Coast from this terrible disaster.

## Passage:
Protecting the Environment
    
    
        After three months of hard work, engineers and scientists from around the world finally stopped the oil spill from the Deepwater Horizon oil rig. They were able to seal the well so no more oil could leak into the ocean water.
During those difficult months, many people worked to protect the waters and beaches around the Gulf of Mexico. One of the first things they did was spread oil booms in the water. An oil boom is like a floating wall that stops oil from spreading. Workers placed these oil booms all along the coast to keep oil away from beaches and wetlands. Once the oil was trapped by the oil booms, special boats came to clean the oil out of the water.

---

Even with all this work, thousands of gallons of oil still washed up on land. Workers spent many months cleaning oil from the beaches. Thanks to lots of hard work, people were able to prevent a complete environmental disaster. We will never know exactly how many fish, shrimp, and other sea animals died from the oil spill, but it could have been much worse. Most importantly, most of the wetlands were saved.
There are many things you can do to help protect the environment. To make things we use every day like bottles, cans, and paper, we need to use a natural resource. A natural resource is something from nature that people use to make products. To make cans, people dig mines and remove metals like aluminum from the earth. Trees are a natural resource used to make paper. Plastic bottles and toys are made from oil, which is also a natural resource.

---

Cans, bottles, and papers can be used again when we recycle them. When you recycle, old items get turned into new ones. This means we need less metal from mines, fewer trees get cut down, and less oil gets used to make new plastic. When we recycle, we help protect the environment!
Today there are over 7 billion people on Earth. About half of all the land is used to grow food for everyone. Towns, cities, and roads cover much of the remaining land. This does not leave much room for forests and other natural places where animals live.

---

People are finding smart ways to protect nature while still using its resources. Tree farms are one example. At a tree farm, workers cut down trees in one section while new trees grow in another section. This way, people can get the wood they need without cutting down all the forests.
People are also working to find cleaner ways to make electricity for homes and schools. Today, most electricity comes from oil and coal. Getting these fuels can cause accidents like oil spills. But we can also use wind and sunlight to make electricity. Giant windmills at wind farms create clean, safe electricity. It is possible to protect the environment and still get all the food and energy we need to live healthy lives.
